items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
1. Evergreen Valley College Adjunct Faculty
Per the collective bargaining agreement between the AFT 6157 and San Jose/Evergreen Community College District Article 9.19 submission and recommendation: Adjunct faculty members shall be responsible and accountable for all District assigned services during the college semester for which they are employed. Assignments are limited to a maximum of 67% of the full load.
				 
Article 9.19 ASSIGNMENT LENGTH AND MAXIMUM LOADING - Adjunct faculty members shall be responsible and accountable for all District assigned service during the college semester for which they are employed. Assignments are limited to a maximum of 67% of a full load.
Therefore, the attached information is in compliance with Article 9.19 of the Faculty Association AFT 6157 Collective Bargaining Agreement with San Jose/Evergreen Community College District.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the faculty personnel action as submitted.

As part of a Joint Powers Agreement with the South Bay Regional Public Safety Training Consortium, it was agreed that employment of instructional staff would be contracted from the member districts.  EVC has historically processed employment for this group and prepares information for approval by the Board of Trustees.

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details:
CTE Enhancement Fund Overview
One time funds to develop, enhance, retool, and expand quality career technical education offerings that build upon existing community college regional capacity to respond to regional labor market needs.
	 
Priority for funding shall go to programs that meet all of the criteria listed above and that meet one or more of the following criteria:
(A) Are in priority sectors identified by the region
(B) Are in emerging sectors identified by the region
(C) Are articulated with K-12 or four year institutions.
	 
60% allocated directly to colleges using a formula factoring in CTE FTES, All FTES, both credit and noncredit.
	 
Funds may be used for
Equipment
Curriculum Development
Professional Development 
Other related costs necessary to develop, enhance, retool, and expand quality CTE offerings
Funding Amount to SJCC: $186, 570
	 
Areas submitted by SJCC:
Precision Instrument and Equipment Repair
Advanced Manufacturing/Machining Technology
Ironwork Apprenticeship program
Carpenter Apprenticeship Program
May also include Patient Navigator/Community Resource online course development
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve and accept the Bay Area Community College Consortium CTE Enhancement Fund.

items.item_details:
CA Education Code Section 72024(3) states that "In any community college district in which FTES for the prior college year was 25,000 or less, but more than 10,000, each member of the governing board of the district who actually attends all meetings held may receive as compensation for his or her services a sum not to exceed four hundred dollars ($400) in any month."
	 
However, Section 72024(e) also states that "On an annual basis, the governing board may increase the compensation of individual board members beyond the limits delineated in this section, in an amount not to exceed 5 percent based on the present monthly rate of compensation. Any increase made pursuant to this section shall be effective upon approval by the governing board. The action may be rejected by a majority of the voters in that district voting in a referendum established for that purpose, as prescribed by Chapter 2 (commencing with Section 9100) of Division 9 of the Elections Code.)"
	 
Please note that current Board monthly compensation is $420 ($400 plus a previously approved 5% increase in 2006.) The Board also participated in a salary reduction along with district staff members from April through June 2011, which was rescinded in July 2011 when district staff members no longer participated in the salary reduction. If the Board approves another 5% increase, it would increase the monthly compensation to $441, effective December 1, 2014.  All governing board members also receive an additional $100 monthly stipend to cover communications costs, such as mailings and cell phone monthly charges associated with district business. 
	 
If the Board approves this action, the monthly compensation for Student Trustees will be increased from $210 to $221 per BP 2725 which states that "Student Trustees shall receive half of the compensation paid to board members."
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees increase its monthly compensation from $420 to $441 and Student Trustee monthly compensation from $210 to $221 effective December 1, 2014.
items.item_text: Increase in Board Compensation
items.item_text_raw: 11. Increase in Board Compensation

items.item_details:
At the October 14, 2014 Board of Trustees meeting, the Board approved an agreement for $270,000 to Cambridge West Partnership, LLC for the Educational Master Plan only (for the entire District), with the understanding that the agreement for the related Facilities Master Plans would be addressed at a later board meeting.  
 
On August 1, 2014 Bid Proposal #14-0825 - for Educational Master Plan (EMP) and Related Facilities Master Plan (FMP) consulting services was advertised. The proposals were assessed and ranked by an evaluation committee comprised of a Purchasing Agent, District Office personnel and personnel from EVC, SJCC, and the Workforce Institute. Of the six vendors who bid for the Facilities Master Plan, three were invited to present to the committee. The evaluation committee selected Cambridge West Partnership, LLC to provide both the EMP and FMP consulting services for the District. Cambridge West Partnership, LLC is a qualified minority and women owned business.
	 
District and campus staff have now clarified the expected scope of services and maximum fee for the Facilities Master Plan, for both campuses, with Cambridge West Partnership.  The attached agreement includes the full expected scope of services for Evergreen Valley College. The negotiated fee is a maximum, not to exceed, amount with a requirement to document billable hours and all expenses.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the award of an Agreement in the amount of (not to exceed) $255,000.00 to Cambridge West Partnership for a new Facilities Master Plan for Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
The installation of the network equipment at 40 S. Market Street will be managed by Dasher Technologies per the ICA that was approved by the Board of Trustees on October 28, 2014 (item G.5). The attached quote is for the fiber cables and horizontal cable management that will connect the network equipment to the structured cabling in the Telecommunications Rooms and Data Center. 
	 
On May 30, 2014, the District issued an RFP (RFP #G2010.0099 SJECCD IT Broker Integrator Infrastructure Services Partner) for broker/integrator services to supply the required hardware and implementation services to complete the build-out of the new data center and network design.  The RFP served to qualify vendors with significant manufacturer relationships and certifications, as well as identify local resources available to assist the District in long-term efforts to complete this significant infrastructure upgrade effort. It was unanimous among the evaluation committee members that Dasher Technologies provided the best solutions for the District.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the purchase of Fiber Cables and Horizontal Cable Management from Dasher Technologies for the network Telecommunications Rooms and Data Center at 40 S. Market Street for $3,291.65. May 30, 2014, the District issued an RFP #G2010.0099 SJECCD IT Broker Integrator Infrastructure Services Partner for broker/interator services.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Fiber Cables and Horizontal Cable Management for Network at 40 S. Market Street
items.item_text_raw: 2. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Fiber Cables and Horizontal Cable Management for Network at 40 S. Market Street

items.item_details:
Background
	 
Friday, January 2, 2015 is scheduled to be the first return to workday after the winter recess.  To bring the facilities to full use for one day and shut down again for the weekend is not energy efficient or cost effective.  It is recommended that the District provide January 2, 2015 as a District Holiday.  The closure will not affect students.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve January 2, 2015, as a District Holiday.
items.item_text: Change January 2, 2015 to a District Holiday
items.item_text_raw: 1. Change January 2, 2015 to a District Holiday

items.item_details:
The Political Reform Act requires every local governmental agency (such as school districts) review its Conflict of Interest Code every even-numbered year. Government Code Section 87303 states that, "No conflict of interest code shall be effective until it has been approved by the code reviewing body." The code-reviewing body for the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District is the County of Santa Clara Board of Supervisors. A draft Conflict of Interest Code for SJECCD was submitted to the Santa Clara Board of Supervisors for review, and the draft was revised and approved by the County Counsel on September 12, 2014. A red-lined version of the code is attached, which reflects the changes made by the County as well as the designated position changes made by the Chancellor and her executive team.
	 
Because the County of Santa Clara Board of Supervisors requires that the governing board of the district approve the code before the final version is submitted by the November 30, 2014, deadline, the district recommends the Board of Trustees approve the attached Conflict of Interest Code.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the district's revised Conflict of Interest Code.
items.item_text: Biennial Review of SJECCD Conflict of Interest Code

items.item_text: Evergreen Valley College Presentation to the Board of Trustees
items.item_text_raw: 1. Evergreen Valley College Presentation to the Board of Trustees

items.item_details:
Background
	 
On February 12, 2013, the San José-Evergreen Community College District Board of Trustees scheduled a “Study Session” and embarked on a transformational journey that concluded on May 13, 2014, with the approval of a revised governance model under the heading   “San José-Evergreen Community College District, Board of Trustees Ends Policies and Governance Principles.”
	 
	 
http://www.sjeccd.edu/Chancellor/Documents/SJECCD%20Board_Ends%20Policies_Governance%20Principles%205%2013%2014.pdf
	 
	 
On October 14, 2014, the Chancellor presented a Workplan describing the "means strategies" to be undertaken by staff, including proposed metrics identified to monitor the implement of  "Boards Global Ends Policies."  This report set the framework for the final step in the implementation of the Board of Trustees Ends Policies and Governance principles; namely; the establishment of the 2015 proposed Calendar of Meetings and Board Agenda.   This calendar and list of items is scheduled to be presented to the Board for approval on December 9, 2014.  In advance of this action this item provides a draft of the material to be approved.  In reviewing these documents, it is important to note three factors:
	 
	 
1.  The Board will be transitioning from a Fiscal Year Calendar (July to June) to a Calendar Year  (January to December).  
2.  The Board's current FY Calendar currently established until June 2015 will have to be revised to accommodate the new timeline (i.e. January 2015 to December 2015)
3.  The Board will be asked will be asked to approve a list of proposed agenda items that include:
a) Regular Cyclical Reports (These are reporting requirements that comply with Ed.Code, Title 5, Board Policies etc.)
b) Ends Policies Accountability Reports (Quarterly reporting on selected Ends Policies (one or two per report)
c) Board Study Sessions (Established and newly requested sessions 2-hrs. or more)
	 
	 
Attached to this item are two draft documents including:
	 
1.  CY 2015 Schedule of Governing Board Meeting Dates and Corresponding Deadlines
2.  CY 2015 Board Calendar (Matrix of Proposed Agenda Items)
3.  Ends Policies Measures
4.  Ends Policies Metrics
5.  Sample Monitoring Reports
items.item_text: Board of Trustees 2015 Agenda Development:Integration of Board's End Policies Monitoring and Accountability Process
items.item_text_raw: 2. Board of Trustees 2015 Agenda Development:Integration of Board's End Policies Monitoring and Accountability Process

items.item_details:
ďťż
On October 14 San Jose City College brought to the Board a request to approve and accept a Title V, Hispanic Serving Institution a five-year grant from the U.S. Department of Education in the amount of $2,478,135.00.  The significance of these resources in shaping the future of SJCC as an effective HSI is noteworthy, beginning with the establishment and future institutionalization of the Caminos Program.  Caminos is designed to put in place student-centered support services based on “high impact practices” that create academic opportunities for the colleges’ highly diverse student population in general, and Hispanic students in particular.  The purpose of this report is to receive information from Mr. David Trujillo, President of the Alliance of Hispanic Service Institutions Educators (AHSIE) regarding the recognized standing attained by SJCC  as a premier HSI and the platform that this grant has established positioning the college to pursue additional resources trough partnership and collaborative program opportunities with four-year colleges and universities.
items.item_text: Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs) Role to Improve Latino(a) College Access and Completion.
items.item_text_raw: 3. Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs) Role to Improve Latino(a) College Access and Completion.
